sections.chapter_name: Economy of São Tomé and Príncipe
openai_summarised_points: • The economy of São Tomé and Príncipe has traditionally been dependent on cocoa production as its primary economic activity.
• The country is currently undergoing significant economic changes driven by investments in the development of its oil industry.
• These investments focus on exploiting oil reserves located in the oil-rich waters of the Gulf of Guinea.
• The shift from a cocoa-dependent economy to one increasingly influenced by oil development marks a notable transformation in São Tomé and Príncipe’s economic landscape.
• The article on the economy of São Tomé and Príncipe requires additional citations from reliable sources to verify the information presented.
• Unsourced material in the article may be challenged and removed, emphasizing the need for scholarly and credible references such as news, newspapers, books, academic journals, and JSTOR.
• The notice requesting additional citations was added in November 2012, indicating ongoing efforts to improve the article’s reliability and accuracy.

sections.chapter_name: Economy of São Tomé and Príncipe
openai_summarised_points: • Under Portuguese colonial rule, sugar plantations were established on the islands of São Tomé and Príncipe.
• During this period, the islands served as a transshipment point for the slave trade.

sections.chapter_name: Economy of São Tomé and Príncipe
openai_summarised_points: • Geologists estimate that the Gulf of Guinea zone, specifically the Niger Delta province, contains more than 10 billion barrels (1.6 km³) of oil, although no oil reserves have been officially proven to date.
• In 2005, São Tomé and Príncipe entered into a joint oil project with Nigeria, which is expected to generate approximately $50 million in government revenue from exploration licence signing fees.
• The $50 million revenue from the 2005 joint oil project represents four times the total government revenues recorded in 2004.
• São Tomé and Príncipe remains optimistic about the potential for significant petroleum discoveries under the exploration licence agreements.
• As of 2021, no crude oil or natural gas has been discovered in São Tomé and Príncipe despite ongoing exploration efforts.

sections.chapter_name: Economy of São Tomé and Príncipe
openai_summarised_points: • Since the 1800s, the economy of São Tomé and Príncipe has been primarily based on plantation agriculture.
• At the time of independence, Portuguese-owned plantations occupied 90% of the cultivated agricultural area in São Tomé and Príncipe.
• Following independence, control of these plantations was transferred to various state-owned agricultural enterprises.
• The dominant agricultural crop on São Tomé is cocoa, which accounts for approximately 95% of the country’s exports.
• Other significant export crops from São Tomé and Príncipe include copra, palm kernels, and coffee.

sections.chapter_name: Economy of São Tomé and Príncipe
openai_summarised_points: • The government of São Tomé and Príncipe implements an economic program that receives support from the International Monetary Fund (IMF) through its Extended Credit Facility arrangement.

sections.chapter_name: Economy of São Tomé and Príncipe
openai_summarised_points: • The gross domestic product (GDP) of São Tomé and Príncipe measured by purchasing power parity was estimated at $316.9 million in 2010, up from $214 million in 2003.
• The real GDP growth rate was estimated at 6% in 2010, showing an increase from 5% in 2004.
• GDP per capita based on purchasing power parity was approximately $1,800 in 2010, compared to $1,200 in 2003.
• The unemployment rate within the formal business sector was estimated at 12.2% in 2017.
• The national budget in 1993 recorded revenues of $58 million and expenditures of $114 million, which included capital expenditures amounting to $54 million.
• Key industries in São Tomé and Príncipe include light construction, textiles, soap manufacturing, beer production, fish processing, and timber.
• Agricultural products consist of cocoa, coconuts, palm kernels, copra, cinnamon, pepper, coffee, bananas, papayas, beans, poultry, and fish.
• Total exports were valued at $13 million in 2010.
• Export commodities in 2009 were dominated by cocoa, which accounted for 80% of exports, followed by copra, coffee, and palm oil.
• Major export partners in 2009 included the United Kingdom (32.99%), the Netherlands (26.93%), Belgium (21.04%), and Portugal (4.31%).
• Imports were estimated at $127.7 million in 2017.
• São Tomé and Príncipe imports all of its required petroleum, indicating no domestic petroleum production.
